exposures-context-help.content:
About Exposures

The Exposure page provides a list of exposures, details about the exposure, evidence, affected assets, and a list of remediations to resolve an exposure, or a group of exposures. Use this information to analyze and address exposures found in your environment.

Threat Levels

Exposures uses icons to help you identify the threat levels of an exposure. See the threat level categories below:

  • High
  • Medium
  • Low
  • Info

Category

There are two types of exposures categoryâ€”security and configuration that Alert Logic lists in the Exposures page.

  • Security exposures are issues related to vulnerabilities identified in a scan, such as an attack or vulnerability that can lead to a breach if not addressed.
  • Configuration exposures are issues related to your deployment can hinder Alert Logic from delivering service properly.

Open Exposures

The Exposures page, by default, will list individual, open exposures. You can also view open remediations, which provide a recommended action to resolve one or multiple exposures. To view the list of remediations, click Organize by Remediation.

On the left-hand filter, you can select one or more available filters to narrow your list of items. Click Dispose to view items removed from the list, or click Concluded to view items that are considered resolved.

Exposures actions

  • Dispose: To hide an item(s) and exclude their calculated vulnerability risks from your environment, select one or more items (exposures or remediations), and then click the Dispose icon ().
  • Conclude:To verify that an item(s) will no longer appear in the next scan, select one or more items, and then click the Conclude icon ().
  • Preview: To expand and see important details on an item, click Preview.
  • Open: To go to the Detail page, and see more information on an item, click Open.
  • Restore: To move an item(s) from the Dispose or Concluded lists back to the Open lists, click the restore ( ) icon.

kevin-was-here.content:
Hi, Mario!

It's me, Kevin!

via GIPHY

So, what are you looking at and how does it work exactly? I will tell you.

Part 1: The Content

The content itself lives in a protected repository. Everything inside its bundles/src directory is compiled via script into compact JSON files, and these are in turn synced to a known location in an S3 bucket. With a little bit of work, we can use the same approach to automatically bundle up HTML and text fragments provided by infodev. These resources can be any inline content -- text, html, JSON, markdown, SVG resources, you name it. Each resource is annotated with its content type and modification timestamp.

Part 2: The API

Gestalt provides a convenient way to retrieve the bundled data from our s3 bucket. This means we don't need to expose an ugly s3 hosted URL to end users, and that we can perform any mapping we need to for different clusters of data, and also that we can customize caching settings to our heart's content. The gestalt endpoint /content/v1/:category/:resource+ is handled by this lambda essentially this just does the sleight-of-hand of retrieving the right content from the right hosted s3 path, and providing a reasonable set of cache-control directives.

Part 3: The Client

A fully fledged client should consolidate requests and cache data locally. I haven't written a very nice client; I'm just GETting the right gestalt resource and extracting a chunk of data, then sanitizing it and inserting it into the DOM. But it works, evidently! Obviously, there's a lot more work that needs to be done, and some questions about shared resources -- like images and icons -- that need to be settled. But it's better than putting stuff into an iframe!

The component source code for this is located here: https://algithub.pd.alertlogic.net/defender/nepal-ng-common-components/tree/master/projects/ng-generic-components/src/lib/al-external-content. Help it!
